title: STOCK WATCH: London Stock Exchange keeps bragging rights
text:
Fresh from shrugging off the unwanted advances of its Hong Kong rival, the London Stock Exchange group is likely to start bragging about the benefits of its £21billion takeover of trading data provider Refinitiv.

A trading update on Friday will give it the opportunity to start afresh and show why it was right to give Hong Kong Exchanges and Clearing short shrift.

A week before pulling out of its £32billion approach, HKEX hired US lobbying firm S-3 Group for ‘government relations services’ – probably to convince US regulators about the deal. But then the MoS revealed HKEX needed £4billion more to win over investors...

The LSE will update investors on trading next Friday

Sirius Minerals

After failing to convince banks and the Government to stump up cash, Sirius Minerals is in a race against time to drum up funds to keep building its fertiliser project in Yorkshire.

Chief executive Chris Fraser previously boasted about his ambition of being a FTSE 100 company. But after its recent share price slump, Sirius could suffer the ignominy of being relegated from the FTSE 250 unless it recovers dramatically.

Ashmore

Emerging market fund manager Ashmore may reveal tomorrow investors have pulled out $500million, say analysts at Swiss bank UBS.

Ashmore was one of the foreign fund managers holding Argentine debt before currency controls were imposed last month as the latest crisis took hold.

Netflix

Netflix is another one to watch on Friday as it announces quarterly subscriber numbers after a disappointing update for April to June. Rivals with deep pockets – Disney, Apple and HBO – are now posing a threat to the streaming service.

Analysts say Netflix’s strategy of spending billions of dollars on content to win viewers may become ‘unsustainable’ if lenders curb borrowing over growth fears. Short-sellers could renew their attack if its crown starts to slip.

Contributor: Harriet Dennys
